strengths.concept_label: Basic Risk: Maximum loss on a long options position
strengths.description: Knows that buying a call caps maximum loss to the premium paid — correctly distinguishes long options from unlimited-risk positions like naked shorts or stock ownership, demonstrating foundational risk awareness.

strengths.concept_label: Time Decay (Theta): How options lose value over time
strengths.description: Correctly identifies Theta as the driver of time-based option value erosion — not delta decay or volatility — showing an understanding of why options are wasting assets and how the clock works against buyers.

strengths.concept_label: Portfolio Protection: Using puts to hedge downside risk
strengths.description: Recognises protective puts as the precise tool for hedging a portfolio against a drawdown while staying fully invested — avoids the common misconceptions of buying more stock (conviction vs. risk management) or liquidating to cash.

strengths.concept_label: Delta: Option price sensitivity to underlying movement
strengths.description: Accurately defines Delta as the dollar sensitivity of an option's price to a $1 move in the underlying stock — correctly distinguishing it from Vega (volatility sensitivity) and Rho (interest rate sensitivity).
Understands that market uncertainty ahead of earnings inflates implied volatility and therefore option premiums — a key insight for timing entries and exits around binary events.

strengths.concept_label: Gamma: Accelerating delta sensitivity near expiry
strengths.description: Correctly understands that high Gamma means small moves in the underlying can cause outsized, non-linear swings in option value — demonstrating awareness of the accelerating risk that builds in short-dated positions.

weaknesses.concept_label: Covered Calls: Income generation from existing holdings
weaknesses.misconception: Chose 'Buy Apple call options' when the goal was income generation against an existing stock position — conflates buying calls (directional speculation, adding exposure) with selling covered calls (income generation, capping upside). Reveals a gap in understanding that covered calls are a *selling* strategy that monetises existing share ownership.

weaknesses.concept_label: Assignment Mechanics: What happens when ITM options expire
weaknesses.misconception: Chose 'You'll lose money' for an ITM covered call expiring in-the-money — misreads assignment as a loss event. In reality, the call seller keeps the full premium AND sells shares at the agreed strike price ($320), which was above cost. Reveals confusion about how a covered call's P&L resolves at expiration.

weaknesses.concept_label: Cash-Secured Puts: Strategic entry at target price with premium income
weaknesses.misconception: Chose 'Buy Netflix call options' when the goal was to acquire the stock at a lower target price — defaults to long calls (a bullish bet on price rising) rather than cash-secured puts, which generate premium income while creating an obligation to buy at the exact desired entry price. Conflates speculation with a disciplined entry strategy.

weaknesses.concept_label: Expiration Management: Actively managing ITM positions near expiry
weaknesses.misconception: Chose 'Let them all expire automatically' when managing 5 in-the-money positions expiring next week — reveals a passive approach to a scenario that demands active risk management. Automatic exercise of multiple ITM positions can trigger unexpected assignment, capital calls, or margin implications that must be evaluated individually.

weaknesses.concept_label: Multi-Leg Strategies: Iron condor mechanics and profit conditions
weaknesses.misconception: Chose 'SPY only goes up' for an iron condor — misreads the strategy as directional rather than range-bound. An iron condor profits when the underlying stays *between* the short strikes, not from directional movement. Reveals an incomplete mental model of how combining a call spread and a put spread creates a neutral profit zone.

weaknesses.concept_label: Volatility Crush: Post-earnings IV collapse and its impact on options
weaknesses.misconception: Chose 'Time decay acceleration' to explain a 30% overnight options loss after earnings — attributes the damage to Theta rather than IV crush. Misses that implied volatility can collapse by 40–60% the moment the earnings event resolves, independently destroying option value even when the stock barely moves and time decay is minimal.

available_actions: Covered calls on your existing stocks
Real-time P&L with your actual tickers
Position sizes up to 10% of portfolio
